title: Stock Market Learning
text:
Stock Market Learning is an international competition run by the <a href="Savings%20bank">Savings Banks</a> in Europe with the support of the <a href="European%20Savings%20Banks%20Group">European Savings Banks Group</a> (ESBG) based in Brussels. It aims to provide pupils a better understanding of the <a href="stock%20market">stock market</a> and of the economic and financial world by simulating transactions in <a href="stock%20exchange">stock exchange</a>s. The competition was held for the first time in Germany in 1983, while the Savings Banks in Europe became actively involved in 1999. By 2010, over 1 million teams had taken part in the initiative.
Procedure.
Each team is assigned an account with virtual capital that is to be used to buy and sell <a href="Security%20%28finance%29">securities</a>. The purpose is to increase initial <a href="asset">asset</a>s by conducting individual investing strategies. While capital is virtual, trading is based on real <a href="Share%20price">stock prices</a> at certain stock exchanges.
The list of tradable securities consists primarily of <a href="Share%20%28finance%29">shares</a> but also includes <a href="Fixed%20interest">fixed-interests</a> securities and <a href="Collective%20investment%20scheme">investment funds</a>. Since 2009, there is both a conventional and <a href="sustainability">sustainability</a> competition. The former takes into consideration the total performance of the account, whereas the latter is based on the sustainability account value, i.e. on the earnings gained from shares listed in a <a href="sustainability%20index">sustainability index</a>.
Awards.
In 2010, Stock Market Learning received the official <a href="United%20Nations%20Decade%20of%20Education%20for%20Sustainable%20Development">UN Decade Project of Education for Sustainable Development</a> award from the German Commission for UNESCO.
